_exec_summary.SummaryText:
San Sebastian Filtration Plant is located at the Carretera 449, Km 0.4 Sector Los Tanques Bo Calabazas, San Sebastian, Puerto Rico, 00685.  This water treatment plant is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.
PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine. The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68. The prevention program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety management (PSM) regulation as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.

Accidental Release:
It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason San Sebastian Filtration Plant is already observing required engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve security and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.
San Sebastian Filtration Plant is located close to the area where the plant supplies the potable water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans.  The chlorine is delivered from the PRASA Storage center in Puerto Nuevo to the plant in 1 ton containers. San Sebastian Plant may have a storage maximum volume of 6,000 pounds distributed in three (3) containers.  Two containers have flexible connection that are connected to the vacuum operated chlorinator valves and through one of them, the dosified chlorine flows to the ejectors where the chlorine is combined with water and then sent to the injections points in the process of the plant. 

Worst Case Scenario:
The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Tre

atment Plant, as per Appendix F, Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants. This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected. 
Using the Landview # 6 simulator and the US Census 2000, it was identified that 6,581 residents are inside the 1.3 miles radio.  ALOHA was used to simulate and map the gas dispersion.

Alternative Case Scenario:
The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 pounds container, but throughout a pipe leak.  In the alternative case the end point distance is calculated as 0.1 miles and five (5) residents are identified over the most recent map according to the Landview/Us Census 2000. 

General Accident Release Prevention Program 
PRASA is actually close to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facilities which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Different Standard Operational Procedures (SOP) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the Chlorine.  List of all SOP?s are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.

Emergency Response Program:
PRASA has various SOP?s to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.

Five years Accident History:
No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) pounds has been reported during the last five years. 

Plann

ed Changes to Improve Safety:
It was recommended that PRASA implemented in San Sebastian Filtration Plant the vacuum operated system directly to the containers to improve the control of the process and the safety of the chlorine handling and storage.  It is still needed to reinforced administrative activities related to containers handling and transportation, employee?s training, personal protective equipment, preventive maintenance and audits. Recommendations were given on that regard on last PHA dated 01/17/2008.
